[in intertitles]
When I came into the room tonight, I saw a face at the window...

[in intertitles]
... the face of a little boy.

[in intertitles]
Two flights up?

[in intertitles]
This is not the first time. Last week, I was drowsing here by the fire...

[in intertitles]
I felt a draught and looked up, and in the center of the room I saw that same little boy.

[in intertitles]
I screamed. Nana sprang at him. The boy leapt out of the window ~ and escaped...

[in intertitles]
... but not before the window had closed and cut his shadow clean off.

[in intertitles]
Mother, dear, what time was I born?

[in intertitles]
At twelve o'clock in the nighttime, precious.

[in intertitles]
Oh, Mummy, I hope I didn't wake you.

[in intertitles]
Can anything harm us, Mummy, dear, after the night lights are lit?

[in intertitles]
Nothing, precious. They are the eyes a mother leaves behind her to guard her children.

[in intertitles]
That boy may come back for his shadow.

[in intertitles]
Dear Wendy, have you gone away?

[in intertitles]
Will you never be here any more to play? Wendy, mother!

[in intertitles]
And I thought it was only flowers that died!

[in intertitles]
Peter, what are your exact feelings for me?

[in intertitles]
Those of a devoted son, Wendy.

[in intertitles]
You're so puzzling. Tiger Lily's just the same. There's something she wants to be to me, but she says it's not my mother.

[in intertitles]
Though the children stayed away for many moons, the beautiful mother always left the window open for them to fly back. I do like a mother's love, don't you?

[in intertitles]
I do just.

[in intertitles]
It isn't that kind of pain. Wendy, you are wrong about mothers. When I flew back to my mother, the window was barred, and there was another little boy asleep in my bed.

[in intertitles]
The first that does not behave toward Wendy like an American gentleman, I will blood him severly.

[in intertitles]
Peter Pan, who and what art thou?

[in intertitles]
I'm youth, I'm joy! I'm a little bird that has broken out of the egg!

[in intertitles]
Oh, Wendy's mother, I don't want to grow up! Don't want to be President!
[first title card]

A NOTE / On the Acting of a Fairy Play / The difference between a Fairy Play and a realistic one is that in the former all the characters are really children with a child's outlook on life. This applies to the so-called adults of the story as well as the young people. Pull the beard off the fairy king, and you would find the face of a child.

This, then, is the spirit of the play. And it is necessary that all of you ~ no matter what age you may have individually attained ~ should be children. PETER PAN will laughingly blow the fairy dust in your eyes and presto! You'll all be back in the nursery, and once more you'll believe in fairies, and the play moves on. / J.M. Barrie

[in intertitles]
Where do you live?

[in intertitles]
Second to the right and then straight on till morning.

[in intertitles]
Well, once upon a time there was a gentleman ~

[in intertitles]
I had rather he had been a lady.

[in intertitles]
There was a lady also ~ and what do you think they had?

[in intertitles]
They had three descendants.

[in intertitles]
I wish they had been white rats.
I won't be bathed, Nana, I won't.
John, wake up! There is a boy here who is to teach us to fly.
[Peter nods]
He's going to take us to the Never Land. He says there are mermaids and redskins.
I say, I'll get up at once... hello, I am up!
You just think lovely, wonderful thoughts, and they lift you up in the air.
Oh Peter, you look like Napolean.
I am like him, he was little too.
[in intertitles]
[to Peter Pan]
Who are you?
